The **2018 Tour de France** was the 105th edition of the [Tour de
France](/wiki/Tour_de_France "Tour de France"), one of cycling's three [Grand
Tours](/wiki/Grand_Tour_\(cycling\) "Grand Tour \(cycling\)"). The 3,351 km
(2,082 mi) race started from [Noirmoutier-en-l'Île](/wiki/Noirmoutier-
en-l%27%C3%8Ele "Noirmoutier-en-l'Île"), in the [Vendée](/wiki/Vend%C3%A9e
"Vendée") department, on 7 July and concluded with the [Champs-Élysées
stage](/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es_stage_in_the_Tour_de_France "Champs-
Élysées stage in the Tour de France") in Paris, on 29 July.[n 1] A total of
176 riders across 22 teams were participating in the 21-stage race. The Tour
was the shortest of the [millennium](/wiki/Millennium "Millennium") and was
the fifth time a tour had set out from Vendée. The race was won for the first
time by [Geraint Thomas](/wiki/Geraint_Thomas "Geraint Thomas") of [Team
Sky](/wiki/Team_Sky "Team Sky"). [Tom Dumoulin](/wiki/Tom_Dumoulin "Tom
Dumoulin") ([Team Sunweb](/wiki/Team_Sunweb_\(men%27s_team\) "Team Sunweb
\(men's team\)")) placed second, with Thomas' teammate and four-time Tour
champion [Chris Froome](/wiki/Chris_Froome "Chris Froome") coming third.

The opening stage was won by [Fernando Gaviria](/wiki/Fernando_Gaviria
"Fernando Gaviria") of [Quick-Step Floors](/wiki/Quick-Step_Floors "Quick-Step
Floors"), who became the Tour's first rider to wear the [general
classification](/wiki/General_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "General
classification in the Tour de France") leader's yellow jersey. [Peter
Sagan](/wiki/Peter_Sagan "Peter Sagan")
([Bora–Hansgrohe](/wiki/Bora%E2%80%93Hansgrohe "Bora–Hansgrohe")) then took
the race lead the following stage. [BMC Racing Team](/wiki/BMC_Racing_Team
"BMC Racing Team") won stage three's [team time trial](/wiki/Team_time_trial
"Team time trial"), putting their rider [Greg Van
Avermaet](/wiki/Greg_Van_Avermaet "Greg Van Avermaet") in yellow. He held the
jersey for eight days until the second high mountain stage, where stage winner
Thomas took the lead. He held it for the rest of the race to become the first
[Welshman](/wiki/Welsh_people "Welsh people") to win the overall race. As a
result, Team Sky—and additionally British riders—won six of the previous seven
Tours dating back to 2012.

Sagan won the [points
classification](/wiki/Points_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "Points
classification in the Tour de France") for the sixth time, [Julian
Alaphilippe](/wiki/Julian_Alaphilippe "Julian Alaphilippe") (Quick-Step
Floors) won the [mountains
classification](/wiki/Mountains_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France
"Mountains classification in the Tour de France"), and [Pierre
Latour](/wiki/Pierre_Latour "Pierre Latour") of [AG2R La
Mondiale](/wiki/AG2R_La_Mondiale "AG2R La Mondiale") won the [young rider
classification](/wiki/Young_rider_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "Young
rider classification in the Tour de France"). [Movistar
Team](/wiki/Movistar_Team_\(men%27s_team\) "Movistar Team \(men's team\)") won
the [team classification](/wiki/Team_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France
"Team classification in the Tour de France"), and [UAE Team
Emirates](/wiki/UAE_Team_Emirates "UAE Team Emirates") rider [Dan
Martin](/wiki/Dan_Martin_\(cyclist\) "Dan Martin \(cyclist\)") was named the
most [combative](/wiki/Combativity_award_in_the_Tour_de_France "Combativity
award in the Tour de France") for the entire race.

## Teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Teams")]

Main article: [List of teams and cyclists in the 2018 Tour de
France](/wiki/List_of_teams_and_cyclists_in_the_2018_Tour_de_France "List of
teams and cyclists in the 2018 Tour de France")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Place_Napol%C3%A9on_de_La_Roche-
sur-Yon_depuis_l%27%C3%A9glise_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-
Place_Napol%C3%A9on_de_La_Roche-sur-
Yon_depuis_l%27%C3%A9glise_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Place_Napol%C3%A9on_de_La_Roche-
sur-Yon_depuis_l%27%C3%A9glise_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Place_Napol%C3%A9on_de_La_Roche-sur-
Yon_depuis_l%27%C3%A9glise_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Place
Napoléon](/w/index.php?title=Place_Napol%C3%A9on&action=edit&redlink=1 "Place
Napoléon \(page does not exist\)")
([fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Place_Napol%C3%A9on_\(La_Roche-sur-Yon\)
"fr:Place Napoléon \(La Roche-sur-Yon\)")) square in [La Roche-sur-
Yon](/wiki/La_Roche-sur-Yon "La Roche-sur-Yon"), hosted the team presentation
ceremony on 5 July.

The 18 [UCI WorldTeams](/wiki/2018_UCI_World_Tour "2018 UCI World Tour") were
automatically invited to the race. On 6 January 2018, organisers of the Tour,
the [Amaury Sport Organisation](/wiki/Amaury_Sport_Organisation "Amaury Sport
Organisation") (ASO), announced the four second-tier [UCI Professional
Continental
teams](/wiki/List_of_2018_UCI_Professional_Continental_and_Continental_teams
"List of 2018 UCI Professional Continental and Continental teams") that
received a [wildcard](/wiki/Wild_card_\(sports\) "Wild card \(sports\)")
invitation to participate in the event. The four teams were
[Cofidis](/wiki/Cofidis_\(cycling_team\) "Cofidis \(cycling team\)"), [Direct
Énergie](/wiki/Direct_%C3%89nergie_\(cycling_team\) "Direct Énergie \(cycling
team\)"), [Fortuneo–Samsic](/wiki/Fortuneo%E2%80%93Samsic "Fortuneo–Samsic"),
from France and Belgium's [Wanty–Groupe
Gobert](/wiki/Wanty%E2%80%93Groupe_Gobert "Wanty–Groupe Gobert"), all of which
have participated in the race before.[2] This meant that new French team
[Vital Concept](/wiki/Vital_Concept_Cycling_Team "Vital Concept Cycling
Team"), with their team leader, sprinter [Bryan Coquard](/wiki/Bryan_Coquard
"Bryan Coquard"), missed out on the race. [Christian
Prudhomme](/wiki/Christian_Prudhomme "Christian Prudhomme") wished the team
the best in their inaugural season.[3] The presentation of the teams—where the
members of each team's roster are introduced in front of the media and local
dignitaries—took place on [Place
Napoleon](/w/index.php?title=Place_Napoleon&action=edit&redlink=1 "Place
Napoleon \(page does not exist\)")
([fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Place_Napol%C3%A9on_\(La_Roche-sur-Yon\)
"fr:Place Napoléon \(La Roche-sur-Yon\)")) in the town of [La Roche-sur-
Yon](/wiki/La_Roche-sur-Yon "La Roche-sur-Yon") on 5 July, two days before the
opening stage.[4]

New rules by the cycling's governing body, the [Union Cycliste
Internationale](/wiki/Union_Cycliste_Internationale "Union Cycliste
Internationale") (UCI) reduced the number of riders per team for [Grand
Tours](/wiki/Grand_Tour_\(cycling\) "Grand Tour \(cycling\)") from 9 to 8,
resulting in a start list total of 176, instead of the usual 198.[5][6] Of
these, 35 competed in their first Tour de France.[7] The total number of
riders that finished the race was 145.[8] The riders came from 30 countries.
Seven countries had more than 10 riders in the race: France (35), Belgium
(19), the Netherlands (13), Italy (13), Australia (11), Germany (11) and Spain
(11).[6] The average age of riders in the race was 29.37 years,[9] ranging
from the 21-year-old [Egan Bernal](/wiki/Egan_Bernal "Egan Bernal") ([Team
Sky](/wiki/Team_Sky "Team Sky")) to the 40-year-old [Franco
Pellizotti](/wiki/Franco_Pellizotti "Franco Pellizotti")
([Bahrain–Merida](/wiki/Bahrain%E2%80%93Merida_Pro_Cycling_Team
"Bahrain–Merida Pro Cycling Team")).[10][11]
[Groupama–FDJ](/wiki/Groupama%E2%80%93FDJ "Groupama–FDJ") had the youngest
average age while Bahrain–Merida had the oldest.[12]

## Pre-race
favourites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Pre-race favourites")]

### Froome[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Froome")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Tour_de_France_2017%2C_froome_%2836124020176%29.jpg/170px-
Tour_de_France_2017%2C_froome_%2836124020176%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tour_de_France_2017,_froome_\(36124020176\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tour_de_France_2017,_froome_\(36124020176\).jpg "Enlarge")

Defending champion [Chris Froome](/wiki/Chris_Froome "Chris Froome")
_(pictured at the[2017 Tour de France](/wiki/2017_Tour_de_France "2017 Tour de
France"))_ had been considered the favourite for the [general
classification](/wiki/General_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "General
classification in the Tour de France").

Defending champion [Chris Froome](/wiki/Chris_Froome "Chris Froome") (Team
Sky) had generally been considered the main favourite for the [general
classification](/wiki/General_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "General
classification in the Tour de France").[13] He had won four out of the last
five editions, and was also the current defending champion at both other Grand
Tours, the [Vuelta a España](/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a "Vuelta a España") and
the [Giro d'Italia](/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia "Giro d'Italia"). However, Froome's
participation was cast into doubt when he returned a urine sample at the [2017
Vuelta a España](/wiki/2017_Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a "2017 Vuelta a España"),
which contained twice the allowed amount of the asthma drug
[salbutamol](/wiki/Salbutamol "Salbutamol"). This was considered not as a
positive doping result, but as an "Adverse Analytical Finding" (AAF), meaning
that he was allowed to continue racing until the case was resolved. He did
however face the possibility of losing his Vuelta victory and all subsequent
results.[14] The ASO were unhappy with the situation, which was very similar
to that of [Alberto Contador](/wiki/Alberto_Contador "Alberto Contador"), who
started the [2011 Tour](/wiki/2011_Tour_de_France "2011 Tour de France") with
his case over a positive test for [clenbuterol](/wiki/Clenbuterol
"Clenbuterol") still unresolved.[15] The UCI conducted an investigation into
the AAF, which was still unresolved at the time that Froome won the [2018 Giro
d'Italia](/wiki/2018_Giro_d%27Italia "2018 Giro d'Italia"). With an outcome
before the start of the Tour unlikely, the ASO attempted to bar Froome from
starting the race, citing article 28 of the race's rules, saying that the
organiser "expressly reserves the right to refuse participation in—or to
exclude from—the event, a team or any of its members whose presence would be
such as to damage the image or reputation of ASO or the event".[16] Froome was
cleared by the UCI on 2 July 2018, with a press statement reading that the
authorities had found sufficient evidence "that Mr Froome’s sample results do
not constitute an AAF".[17] He was thereafter cleared to start the Tour by the
ASO as well.[18]

### Others[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Others")]

The closest rivals of Froome were thought to be [Richie
Porte](/wiki/Richie_Porte "Richie Porte") (BMC Racing Team), [Nairo
Quintana](/wiki/Nairo_Quintana "Nairo Quintana"), [Mikel
Landa](/wiki/Mikel_Landa "Mikel Landa") (both of Movistar Team), [Tom
Dumoulin](/wiki/Tom_Dumoulin "Tom Dumoulin") (Team Sunweb), and [Vincenzo
Nibali](/wiki/Vincenzo_Nibali "Vincenzo Nibali") (Bahrain–Merida).[19] The
other riders considered contenders for the general classification were
[Geraint Thomas](/wiki/Geraint_Thomas "Geraint Thomas") (Team Sky), [Romain
Bardet](/wiki/Romain_Bardet "Romain Bardet") (AG2R La Mondiale), [Primož
Roglič](/wiki/Primo%C5%BE_Rogli%C4%8D "Primož Roglič") (LottoNL–Jumbo), [Adam
Yates](/wiki/Adam_Yates_\(cyclist\) "Adam Yates \(cyclist\)")
(Mitchelton–BikeExchange), [Jakob Fuglsang](/wiki/Jakob_Fuglsang "Jakob
Fuglsang") (Astana), [Alejandro Valverde](/wiki/Alejandro_Valverde "Alejandro
Valverde") (Movistar Team), [Rigoberto Urán](/wiki/Rigoberto_Ur%C3%A1n
"Rigoberto Urán") (EF Education First–Drapac p/b Cannondale), [Dan
Martin](/wiki/Dan_Martin_\(cyclist\) "Dan Martin \(cyclist\)") (UAE Team
Emirates), [Bob Jungels](/wiki/Bob_Jungels "Bob Jungels") (Quick-Step Floors)
and [Ilnur Zakarin](/wiki/Ilnur_Zakarin "Ilnur Zakarin") (Team
Katusha–Alpecin).[13][20][21][22][23][24][25][26][27][28]

The [sprinters](/wiki/Sprinter_\(cycling\) "Sprinter \(cycling\)") considered
favourites for the [points
classification](/wiki/Points_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "Points
classification in the Tour de France") and wins on the flat or hilly [bunch
sprint](/wiki/Bunch_sprint "Bunch sprint") finishes were [Peter
Sagan](/wiki/Peter_Sagan "Peter Sagan") (Bora–Hansgrohe), [Fernando
Gaviria](/wiki/Fernando_Gaviria "Fernando Gaviria") (Quick-Step Floors),
[Dylan Groenewegen](/wiki/Dylan_Groenewegen "Dylan Groenewegen")
(LottoNL–Jumbo), [Arnaud Démare](/wiki/Arnaud_D%C3%A9mare "Arnaud Démare")
(Groupama–FDJ), [Marcel Kittel](/wiki/Marcel_Kittel "Marcel Kittel") (Team
Katusha–Alpecin), [Michael Matthews](/wiki/Michael_Matthews_\(cyclist\)
"Michael Matthews \(cyclist\)") (Team Sunweb), [Mark
Cavendish](/wiki/Mark_Cavendish "Mark Cavendish") (Team Dimension Data),
[André Greipel](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Greipel "André Greipel") (Lotto–Soudal),
[Alexander Kristoff](/wiki/Alexander_Kristoff "Alexander Kristoff") (UAE Team
Emirates), [Sonny Colbrelli](/wiki/Sonny_Colbrelli "Sonny Colbrelli")
(Bahrain–Merida) and [John Degenkolb](/wiki/John_Degenkolb "John Degenkolb")
(Trek–Segafredo).[29][30][31]

## Route and
stages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Route and stages")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Les_derni%C3%A8res_%C3%A9pingles_de_l%27ascension_du_col_du_portet.jpg/220px-
Les_derni%C3%A8res_%C3%A9pingles_de_l%27ascension_du_col_du_portet.jpg)](/wiki/File:Les_derni%C3%A8res_%C3%A9pingles_de_l%27ascension_du_col_du_portet.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Les_derni%C3%A8res_%C3%A9pingles_de_l%27ascension_du_col_du_portet.jpg
"Enlarge")

The highest point of elevation in the race was the [Col de
Portet](/wiki/Col_de_Portet "Col de Portet") Pyrenean pass, at 2,215 m (7,267
ft). It was used for the first time in the Tour de France.

On 12 February 2017 at a [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") match
between France and Scotland at the [Stade de France](/wiki/Stade_de_France
"Stade de France"), the Tour's race director [Christian
Prudhomme](/wiki/Christian_Prudhomme "Christian Prudhomme") announced the
start of the 2018 Tour (known as the [_Grand
Départ_](/wiki/List_of_Tour_de_France_Grands_D%C3%A9parts "List of Tour de
France Grands Départs")) would be in the [Vendée](/wiki/Vend%C3%A9e "Vendée")
department, in the [Pays de la Loire](/wiki/Pays_de_la_Loire "Pays de la
Loire") region. The departments in the Pays de la Loire region hosted the Tour
de France in its first edition back in 1903. Since then, the cities and towns
of the Pays de la Loire region have welcomed the _Grand Départ_ of the Tour de
France nine times, five of which have set out from the Vendée. The last time
the region hosted the Tour was in [2011](/wiki/2011_Tour_de_France "2011 Tour
de France").[32] Two weeks after the announcement, the ASO revealed that the
_Grand Départ_ would take place over three stages, with the third a [team time
trial](/wiki/Team_time_trial "Team time trial").[33] In June 2017, the UCI’s
Professional Cycling Council (PCC) moved the start of the Tour a week later
than usual and originally planned due to a clash with the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup").[1] The full route was
announced on 17 October 2017; it was almost completely within France, with
short deviations into Spain in the [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees "Pyrenees") were
the only exceptions. It would feature two of the Tour's most historic climbs,
[Alpe d'Huez](/wiki/Alpe_d%27Huez "Alpe d'Huez") and the [Col de
Tourmalet](/wiki/Col_de_Tourmalet "Col de Tourmalet"), which last featured in
2015 and 2016 respectively. For the first time in 60 to 70 years, it included
a section of unpaved roads on the [Glières Plateau](/wiki/Gli%C3%A8res_Plateau
"Glières Plateau").[34] Of the route, Mark Cavendish labelled it "absolutely
brutal".[35]

There were 21 stages in the race, covering a total distance of 3,351 km (2,082
mi), the shortest of the 21st century.[36][37] The race also included 21.7 km
(13.5 mi) of cobblestones (or [pavés](/wiki/Pav%C3%A9 "Pavé")) in stage 9,
which were last featured in 2015. In the first week of the race, two laps of
the short, but steep, [Mûr-de-Bretagne](/wiki/M%C3%BBr-de-Bretagne "Mûr-de-
Bretagne") were included.[34]

## Race
overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Race overview")]

Main articles: [2018 Tour de France, Stage 1 to Stage
11](/wiki/2018_Tour_de_France,_Stage_1_to_Stage_11 "2018 Tour de France, Stage
1 to Stage 11") and [2018 Tour de France, Stage 12 to Stage
21](/wiki/2018_Tour_de_France,_Stage_12_to_Stage_21 "2018 Tour de France,
Stage 12 to Stage 21")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Avermaet_leads_peloton_through_St_Mayeux%2C_2018_TDF_%2841611979480%29.jpg/220px-
Avermaet_leads_peloton_through_St_Mayeux%2C_2018_TDF_%2841611979480%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avermaet_leads_peloton_through_St_Mayeux,_2018_TDF_\(41611979480\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Avermaet_leads_peloton_through_St_Mayeux,_2018_TDF_\(41611979480\).jpg
"Enlarge")

The [peloton](/wiki/Peloton "Peloton") during the finale of the sixth stage

Stage one's bunch sprint was won by Tour debutant Fernando Gaviria, with Peter
Sagan coming in second and Marcel Kittel in third. Gaviria took the yellow and
green jerseys as the leader of the general and points classifications
respectively. [Kévin Ledanois](/wiki/K%C3%A9vin_Ledanois "Kévin Ledanois")
(Fortuneo–Samsic) took the first [polka dot](/wiki/Polka_dot "Polka dot")
jersey as the leader of the [mountains
classification](/wiki/Mountains_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France
"Mountains classification in the Tour de France").[38] Sagan won stage two
from a sprint to take the yellow and green jerseys, with [Dion
Smith](/wiki/Dion_Smith "Dion Smith") of Wanty–Groupe Gobert claiming the
polka.[39] Stage three's [team time trial](/wiki/Team_time_trial "Team time
trial") was won by BMC Racing Team whose riders [Tejay van
Garderen](/wiki/Tejay_van_Garderen "Tejay van Garderen") and [Greg Van
Avermaet](/wiki/Greg_Van_Avermaet "Greg Van Avermaet") became tied for the
overall lead,[40] with Van Avermaet moving into yellow for the second time in
his career due to him crossing the finish line ahead of Van Garderen in the
first two stages being as there was not yet an individual time trial to
measure their times down to the 1000th of a second.[41] Stage four was won by
Gaviria from a bunch sprint.[42][43] Sagan further extend his lead in the
points competition by winning stage five. Also in stage five, [Toms
Skujiņš](/wiki/Toms_Skuji%C5%86%C5%A1 "Toms Skujiņš") of Trek–Segafredo won
the mountains points which gave him the polka. Skujins became the first rider
from [Latvia](/wiki/Latvia "Latvia") to ever lead the mountains
classification.[44]

Stage six was a sprint that Sagan and John Degenkolb raced for, seeing as
virtually all of the top sprinters finished close to fifteen minutes behind
the general classification contenders. Team Sky, BMC Racing Team, and Movistar
Team controlled the [peloton](/wiki/Peloton "Peloton"), where Geraint Thomas
reeled in the final breakaway rider and won the three second time bonus sprint
that put him back only three seconds behind Van Avermaet in the general
classification. With only about a kilometre to go Dan Martin attacked and was
able to stay away and win the stage one second ahead of the bulk of the
general classification contenders. Romain Bardet and Tom Dumoulin suffered
mechanical issues late in the stage which made them lose time.[45][46] Stage
seven was the longest stage. At the start of stage seven, Van Avermaet
remained in the yellow jersey with Thomas in second at three seconds behind.
The stage was won by Dylan Groenewegen. There were multiple crashes in the
first week of the tour and after stage seven, six riders had abandoned the
race for various reasons including the promising young Belgian [Tiesj
Benoot](/wiki/Tiesj_Benoot "Tiesj Benoot")
([Lotto–Soudal](/wiki/Lotto%E2%80%93Soudal "Lotto–Soudal")), [Luis León
Sánchez](/wiki/Luis_Le%C3%B3n_S%C3%A1nchez "Luis León Sánchez") (Astana),[47]
and the green jersey winner of the 2017 Tour Michael Matthews.[48] This marked
the end of the first week of the tour.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Tour_de_France_2018_%2829571589858%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-
Tour_de_France_2018_%2829571589858%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tour_de_France_2018_\(29571589858\)_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tour_de_France_2018_\(29571589858\)_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Greg Van Avermaet](/wiki/Greg_Van_Avermaet "Greg Van Avermaet") ([BMC Racing
Team](/wiki/BMC_Racing_Team "BMC Racing Team")) wearing the race leader's
yellow on one of stage nine's [pavé](/wiki/Sett_\(paving\) "Sett \(paving\)")
sectors. He held the jersey from stage three to ten.

Groenewegen then won his second sprint stage in a row. Notably, Greipel and
Gaviria were penalized for headbutting each other and lost their placing and
green jersey points.[49] Martin lost more than a minute after being involved
in a crash during the stage. Van Avermaet improved his lead in the general
classification after earning a single second in the bonus sprint.[50] Stage
nine was the cobblestone stage that was a bad day for numerous sprinters and
general classification riders. Richie Porte abandoned after a crash for the
second year in a row.[51] Egan Bernal, Jakob Fuglsang, Chris Froome, and Mikel
Landa crashed as did many other riders; many riders had flat tires as well,
including Bardet who got three of them.[52] Meanwhile, [Yves
Lampaert](/wiki/Yves_Lampaert "Yves Lampaert") (Quick-Step Floors), Degenkolb,
and Van Avermaet survived the carnage going on around them to escape the
remaining peloton and cross the finish together with Degenkolb winning his
first Tour stage, as Van Avermaet gained time as well as another time bonus to
extend his lead in the yellow jersey.[53] The following day was the Tour's
first rest day.[36]

The first stage at high altitude and first in the Alps, the tenth, was won by
Quick-Step Floors rider [Julian Alaphilippe](/wiki/Julian_Alaphilippe "Julian
Alaphilippe") from a large breakaway that included race leader Van Avermaet.
Eventually, Alaphillipe attacked and won his first Tour stage while Van
Avermaet retained his yellow jersey and extended his lead to nearly two and a
half minutes,[54] when many people thought he would not be retaining it.[55]
Alaphillipe also took the mountains classification.[54] Thomas achieved back-
to-back summit finish wins both from the group of favourites on stages eleven
and twelve by pushing the breakaway riders until the very end. In the steep
finish of the eleventh, Thomas attacked in the final kilometre and passed lone
breakaway rider [Mikel Nieve](/wiki/Mikel_Nieve "Mikel Nieve")
(Mitchelton–Scott) to take the win.[56] He won stage twelve from a sprint on
flat finish atop Alpe d'Huez. Dumoulin and Froome arose as the likely
contenders in Paris.[57] Sagan won stage thirteen after coming out of nowhere
while Kristoff and [Arnaud Démare](/wiki/Arnaud_D%C3%A9mare "Arnaud Démare")
(Groupama–FDJ) dueled it out.[58] In stage fourteen, [Omar
Fraile](/wiki/Omar_Fraile "Omar Fraile") of Astana came out of the breakaway
and remarkably opened a twenty-minute gap to the main peloton with the yellow
jersey contenders. After the Alps, it was basically down to three riders in
contention, Thomas, Froome, and Dumoulin. There were many withdrawals after
the Alps after names like Kittel, Mark Cavendish, Rigoberto Uran, Gaviria,
Groenewegen, and Andre Griepel withdrew for various reasons. Vincenzo Nibali
was forced to withdraw after fracturing a [vertebrae](/wiki/Vertebrae
"Vertebrae") in his back after being involved in an accident with a spectator
near the summit of Alpe d'huez. Smoke from [flares](/wiki/Flare "Flare") and
animosity towards Froome were a factor and better security was called for by
many people for the final week.[59]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/2018_Tour_de_France_-19_Col_d%27Aubisque_%2829846641378%29.jpg/220px-2018_Tour_de_France_-19_Col_d%27Aubisque_%2829846641378%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Tour_de_France_-19_Col_d%27Aubisque_\(29846641378\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2018_Tour_de_France_-19_Col_d%27Aubisque_\(29846641378\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Tom Dumoulin](/wiki/Tom_Dumoulin "Tom Dumoulin") of [Team
Sunweb](/wiki/Team_Sunweb_\(men%27s_team\) "Team Sunweb \(men's team\)")
(left) placed second to [Team Sky](/wiki/Team_Sky "Team Sky")'s [Geraint
Thomas](/wiki/Geraint_Thomas "Geraint Thomas") (right) _(pictured on stage
nineteen)_ in the final [general
classification](/wiki/General_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "General
classification in the Tour de France").

Stage fifteen, the start of the final week, was once again a breakaway
victory. [Magnus Cort](/wiki/Magnus_Cort "Magnus Cort") took Astana's second
win in two days as there were no major changes overall.[60] The next day was
the second rest day of the race.[36] Stage sixteen had a further incident when
the police used [tear gas](/wiki/Tear_gas "Tear gas") against a protest by
local farmers who had placed hay bales on the road. As the riders passed that
point, there was still gas in the air. The race was neutralized for about
fifteen minutes because several riders had problems with their eyes and had to
rinse them.[61] After the restart, a large breakaway escaped and [Philippe
Gilbert](/wiki/Philippe_Gilbert "Philippe Gilbert") (Quick-Step Floors), while
in the lead on a descent, lost control of his bike and smashed into and over
the wall. Later, Adam Yates, having taken the lead, fell on the final descent
and handed the position and win to Alaphilippe, giving him his second stage
win of the tour.[62]

On the first of the three Pyrenan stages, seventeen, Froome's challenge faded
on the approach to the summit of the Col de Portet and he dropped to third
position in the general classification, 2:31 behind Thomas. Dumoulin moved
into second place, 1:59 off the lead. Nairo Quintana won the stage after
attacking at the bottom of the final climb, moving himself up to fifth
overall, behind Primož Roglič.[63] The flat stage eighteen was won by Demare
from a sprint finish; by now most of the top sprint had now left the race and
Sagan was suffering with injury.[64] On the mountainous stage nineteen from
[Lourdes](/wiki/Lourdes "Lourdes") to [Laruns](/wiki/Laruns "Laruns"), Roglič
attacked on the final climb, the [Col d'Aubisque](/wiki/Col_d%27Aubisque "Col
d'Aubisque"), and soloed to the finish nineteen seconds ahead of the chasing
group of overall favourites. Thomas was able to consolidate his position in
the yellow jersey by picking up six bonus seconds in the sprint thereby
extending his lead over Dumoulin to 2 min 5 s.[65] The penultimate stage was a
31 km (19.3 mi) time trial, Dumoulin won the stage, one second ahead of
Froome. Thomas survived a scare when his back wheel locked, but completed the
time trial successfully, finishing fourteen seconds behind Dumoulin taking a
lead of 1 min 51 s into the final stage.[66] The stage was won by Kristoff in
a bunch sprint on the Champs-Élysées in Paris.[67]

## Classification
leadership[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Tour_de_France&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Classification leadership")]

Four main individual classifications were contested in the 2018 Tour de
France, as well as a team competition. The most important was the general
classification, calculated by adding each rider's finishing times on each
stage.[68] Time bonuses were awarded at the end of every stage apart from the
time trial stages. The first three riders would get 10, 6, and 4 seconds,
respectively. Time bonuses of three, two and one seconds, would be given to
the first three riders to cross a "bonus point" in each of the first nine
mass-start stages of the race. It would affect the general classification, but
not the points.[69] For crashes within the final 3 km (1.9 mi) of a stage, not
including time trials and summit finishes, any rider involved would receive
the same time as the group he was in when the crash occurred.[70] The rider
with the lowest cumulative time would be the winner of the general
classification and the overall winner of the Tour.[68] The rider leading the
classification would wear a yellow jersey.[71]

The second classification was the points classification. Riders received
points for finishing among the highest placed in a stage finish, or in
[intermediate sprints](/wiki/Intermediate_sprint "Intermediate sprint") during
the stage. The points available for each stage finish were determined by the
stage's type.[72] The leader was identified by a green jersey.[71]

The third classification was the mountains classification. Points were awarded
to the riders that reached the summit of the most difficult climbs first. The
climbs were categorized, in order of increasing difficulty, as fourth-,
third-, second-, and first-category and _[hors
catégorie](/wiki/Hors_cat%C3%A9gorie "Hors catégorie")_ (read: "beyond
category").[72] Double points were awarded at the top of the last mountains in
the three mountain stages in the Pyrenees (16, 17 and 19).[73] The leader wore
a white jersey with red polka dots.[71]

The final individual classification was the [young rider
classification](/wiki/Young_rider_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "Young
rider classification in the Tour de France"). This was calculated the same way
as the general classification, but was restricted to riders born on or after 1
January 1993.[72] The leader wears a white jersey.[71]

The final classification was a [team
classification](/wiki/Team_classification_in_the_Tour_de_France "Team
classification in the Tour de France"). This was calculated using the
finishing times of the best three riders per team on each stage; the leading
team was the team with the lowest cumulative time. The number of stage
victories and placings per team determined the outcome of a tie.[72] The
riders in the team that lead this classification are identified with yellow
number bibs on the back of their jerseys and yellow
[helmets](/wiki/Bicycle_helmet "Bicycle helmet").[74]

In addition, there was a [combativity
award](/wiki/Combativity_award_in_the_Tour_de_France "Combativity award in the
Tour de France") given after each stage to the rider considered, by a jury, to
have "made the greatest effort and who demonstrated the best qualities of
sportsmanship".[69] No combativity awards are given for the time trials and
the final stage.[75] The winner wore a red number bib the following stage.[76]
At the conclusion of the Tour, a rider would win the overall super-combativity
award which was, again, awarded by a jury.[69]

A total of €2,287,750 was awarded in cash prizes in the race.[75] The overall
winner of the general classification received €500,000, with the second and
third placed riders getting €200,000 and €100,000 respectively.[77] All
finishers in the top 160 were awarded money.[77] The holders of the
classifications would benefit on each stage they led; the final winners of the
points and mountains would be given €25,000, while the best young rider and
most combative rider would get €20,000.[78] The team classification winners
was given €50,000.[79] €11,000 was given to the winners of each stage of the
race, with smaller amounts given to places 2–20.[77] There were also two
special awards each with a prize of €5000.[75] The [Souvenir Henri
Desgrange](/wiki/Souvenir_Henri_Desgrange "Souvenir Henri Desgrange"), given
to first rider to pass the summit of the highest climb in the Tour, the Col du
Portet on stage seventeen,[80] and the [Souvenir Jacques
Goddet](/wiki/Souvenir_Jacques_Goddet "Souvenir Jacques Goddet"), given to the
first rider to pass [Goddet](/wiki/Jacques_Goddet "Jacques Goddet")'s memorial
at the summit of the Col du Tourmalet in stage nineteen.[75] Nairo Quintana
won the Henri Desgrange and Julian Alaphilippe won the Jacques Goddet.[81][82]
